etymology.description: 芥(mustard/Brassica) + 蓝/藍(indigo/blue; used in plant names) = a Brassica leafy vegetable (Chinese broccoli).
etymology.interpretation: Names a Brassica oleracea cultivar with thick stems and broad leaves, common in southern Chinese cuisines. In Mandarin it’s pronounced jièlán; the form gàilán reflects Cantonese gai3 laan4.
etymology.simplification: 蓝 is the simplified form of 藍; 芥 is unchanged. (A variant writes it as 芥兰/芥蘭 in some regions.)

examples.chinese: 我喜欢清炒芥蓝(我喜歡清炒芥藍)。
examples.english: I like stir-frying Chinese broccoli with just oil and garlic.

examples.chinese: 粤菜里，芥蓝常和牛肉一起炒(粵菜裡，芥藍常和牛肉一起炒)。
examples.pinyin: Yuècài lǐ, jièlán cháng hé niúròu yìqǐ chǎo.
examples.english: In Cantonese cuisine, Chinese broccoli is often stir-fried with beef.

examples.chinese: 市场上新鲜的芥蓝很脆甜(市場上新鮮的芥藍很脆甜)。
examples.pinyin: Shìchǎng shang xīnxiān de jièlán hěn cuìtián.
examples.english: Fresh Chinese broccoli at the market is crisp and sweet.
